newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean 3-yr yields end higher on intervention.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean 3-yr yields end higher on intervention.

text.p: Yields on three-year benchmark corporate bonds closed slightly higher on Friday after the central bank soaked up 1.59 trillion won, dealers said.
But overnight call rate fell, reflecting banks' fluid liquidity situation.
Yields on three-year corporate bonds closed higher on Friday as the central bank stepped in by siphoning off liquidity in the market, dealers said.
The central bank absorbed a total of 1.59 trillion won from the banking system in repurchase agreements and monetary stabilisation bonds issues.
But the overnight call rate fell slightly as banks remained liquid despite the central bank's intervention.
Dealers forecast the corporate yields would fall next week.

"Given expected 711.5 billion won worth of new issues due next week, which are managible, and stabilising short-term interest rate, the three-year yields would show a gradual decline," said a Daishin Securities dealer.
A Dongsuh Securities dealer forecast the corporate would move in a 12.10-12.25 percent range next week.
